Information.Help: Boot Feature Configuration Page
Enables or disables Quiet Boot option
Set display mode for Option ROM
Select the keyboard NumLock state
Enable- BIOS will wait for user to press "F1" if some error happens. Disable- BIOS will continue to POST, user interaction not required
BIOS reaction on INT19 trapping by Option ROM: IMMEDIATE - execute the trap right away; POSTPONED - execute the trap during legacy boot.
Decide how to retry boot devices which fail to boot.
Emulation of Port 61h bit-4 toggling in SMM
Enable or disable to turn on 5-minute watch dog timer. Upon timeout, JWD1 jumper determines system behavior.
Instant Off: Turn off system immediately in legacy OS. 4 Seconds Override: Turn off system after depressed for 4 seconds.
Stay Off: System always remains off. Power On: System always turns on. Last State: System returns to previous state before AC lost.
CPU Configuration
Enables Hyper Threading (Software Method to Enable/Disable Logical Processor threads.
Number of Cores to Enable in each Processor Package. 0 means all cores. Total 16 cores available in each CPU package.
When disabled, forces the XD feature flag to always return 0.
When enabled, a VMM can utilize the additional hardware capabilities provided by Vanderpool Technology
Unlock and Enable/Disable PPIN Control
= MLC Streamer Prefetcher (MSR 1A4h Bit[0])
= MLC Spatial Prefetcher (MSR 1A4h Bit[1])
DCU streamer prefetcher is an L1 data cache prefetcher (MSR 1A4h [2]).
DCU IP prefetcher is an L1 data cache prefetcher (MSR 1A4h [3]).
Enable/Disable LLC Prefetch on all threads
Enable/disable extended APIC support
Enable/disable AES-NI support
Displays and provides option to change the Power Management Settings
Switch CPU Power Management profile
MSR 1FCh Bit[25] = PWR_PERF_TUNING_CFG_MODE. Enable - Use IA32_ENERGY_PERF_BIAS input from the core; Disable - Use alternate perf BIAS input from ENERGY_PERF_BIAS_CONFIG
Information.WorkIf: ( 2 == Power Technology ) and ( 2 != Hardware P-States )

Information.Help: Use input from ENERGY_PERF_BIAS_CONFIG mode selection. PERF/Balanced Perf/Balanced Power/Power
Information.WorkIf: ( 2 == Power Technology ) and ( 0 != Power Performance Tuning )

Information.Help: Energy Efficient Turbo Disable, MSR 0x1FC [19]
Enable/Disable processor Turbo Mode (requires EMTTM enabled too).

Information.Help: Disable: Hardware chooses a P-state based on OS Request (Legacy P-States) Native Mode:Hardware chooses a P-state based on OS guidance Out of Band Mode:Hardware autonomously chooses a P-state (no OS guidance)

Menu.name: Chipset Configuration

Information.Help: System Chipset configuration.

Menu.Subtitle: WARNING: Setting wrong values in below sections may cause
system to malfunction.

Information.Help: North Bridge Parameters
Displays and provides option to change the Memory Settings
Enable - Enforces Plan Of Record restrictions for DDR4 frequency and voltage programming. Disable - Disables this feature. Auto - Sets it to the MRC default setting; current default is Enable.
Maximum Memory Frequency Selections in Mhz. Do not select Reserved
Enable - Enables data scrambling for DDR4. Disable - Disables this feature. Auto - Sets it to the MRC default setting; current default is Enable.
Auto: tCCD_L Relaxation will be enabled for selected & capable DIMMs. Disable: tCCD_L Relaxation is always disabled.
Select 2x refresh mode
Displays memory topology with Dimm population information
Displays and provides option to change the Memory Ras Settings
Enable Static Virtual Lockstep mode
Mirror Mode will set entire 1LM memory in system to be mirrored, consequently reducing the memory capacity by half. Mirror Enable will disable XPT Prefetch
Enable/Disable Memory Rank Sparing. This feature is only available on 1LM
Information.WorkIf: ( 1 != Mirror mode ) && ( 1 != Volatile Memory Mode )

Information.Help: Set Multi Rank Sparing number, default and the maximum is 2 ranks per channel
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Memory Rank Sparing

Information.Help: Correctable Error Threshold (1 - 32767) used for sparing, tagging, and leaky bucket
Enable/Disable SDDC. Not supported when AEP dimm present!
Enable/Disable ADDDC Sparing
Enable/Disable Patrol Scrub
Selects the number of hours (1-24) required to complete full scrub. A value of zero means auto!
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Patrol Scrub

South Bridge Parameters
Enables Legacy USB support. AUTO option disables legacy support if no USB devices are connected. DISABLE option will keep USB devices available only for EFI applications.
This is a workaround for OSes without XHCI hand-off support. The XHCI ownership change should be claimed by XHCI driver.
Enables I/O port 60h/64h emulation support. This should be enabled for the complete USB keyboard legacy support for non-USB aware OSes.

Enables or Disables 64bit capable Devices to be Decoded in Above 4G Address Space (Only if System Supports 64 bit PCI Decoding).
If system has SR-IOV capable PCIe Devices, this option Enables or Disables Single Root IO Virtualization Support.
Re-enable Bus Master Attribute disabled during Pci enumeration for PCI Bridges after SMM Locked
Select MMIO High Base

Selects the allocation size used to assign mmioh resources. Total mmioh space can be up to 32xgranularity. Per stack mmioh resource assignments are multiples of the granularity where 1 unit per stack is the default allocation.
Set Maximum Read Request Size of PCI Express Device or allow System BIOS to select the value.

Information.Help: Serial Port Console Redirection
Console Redirection Enable or Disable.
The settings specify how the host computer and the remote computer (which the user is using) will exchange data. Both computers should have the same or compatible settings.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != Console Redirection$1 )

Information.Help: Emulation: ANSI: Extended ASCII char set. VT100: ASCII char set. VT100+: Extends VT100 to support color, function keys, etc. VT-UTF8: Uses UTF8 encoding to map Unicode chars onto 1 or more bytes.
Selects serial port transmission speed. The speed must be matched on the other side. Long or noisy lines may require lower speeds.
Data Bits

A parity bit can be sent with the data bits to detect some transmission errors. Even: parity bit is 0 if the num of 1's in the data bits is even. Odd: parity bit is 0 if num of 1's in the data bits is odd. Mark: parity bit is always 1. Space: Parity bit is always 0. Mark and Space Parity do not allow for error detection. They can be used as an additional data bit.
Stop bits indicate the end of a serial data packet. (A start bit indicates the beginning). The standard setting is 1 stop bit. Communication with slow devices may require more than 1 stop bit.

Flow control can prevent data loss from buffer overflow. When sending data, if the receiving buffers are full, a 'stop' signal can be sent to stop the data flow. Once the buffers are empty, a 'start' signal can be sent to re-start the flow. Hardware flow control uses two wires to send start/stop signals.
Enable VT-UTF8 Combination Key Support for ANSI/VT100 terminals
With this mode enabled only text will be sent. This is to capture Terminal data.
Enables or disables extended terminal resolution
On Legacy OS, the Number of Rows and Columns supported redirection
Select FunctionKey and KeyPad on Putty.

When Bootloader is selected, then Legacy Console Redirection is disabled before booting to legacy OS. When Always Enable is selected, then Legacy Console Redirection is enabled for legacy OS. Default setting for this option is set to Always Enable.
Console Redirection Enable or Disable.
The settings specify how the host computer and the remote computer (which the user is using) will exchange data. Both computers should have the same or compatible settings.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != Console Redirection$2 )

Information.Help: Emulation: ANSI: Extended ASCII char set. VT100: ASCII char set. VT100+: Extends VT100 to support color, function keys, etc. VT-UTF8: Uses UTF8 encoding to map Unicode chars onto 1 or more bytes.
Selects serial port transmission speed. The speed must be matched on the other side. Long or noisy lines may require lower speeds.
Data Bits

A parity bit can be sent with the data bits to detect some transmission errors. Even: parity bit is 0 if the num of 1's in the data bits is even. Odd: parity bit is 0 if num of 1's in the data bits is odd. Mark: parity bit is always 1. Space: Parity bit is always 0. Mark and Space Parity do not allow for error detection. They can be used as an additional data bit.
Stop bits indicate the end of a serial data packet. (A start bit indicates the beginning). The standard setting is 1 stop bit. Communication with slow devices may require more than 1 stop bit.

Flow control can prevent data loss from buffer overflow. When sending data, if the receiving buffers are full, a 'stop' signal can be sent to stop the data flow. Once the buffers are empty, a 'start' signal can be sent to re-start the flow. Hardware flow control uses two wires to send start/stop signals.
Enable VT-UTF8 Combination Key Support for ANSI/VT100 terminals
With this mode enabled only text will be sent. This is to capture Terminal data.
Enables or disables extended terminal resolution
On Legacy OS, the Number of Rows and Columns supported redirection
Select FunctionKey and KeyPad on Putty.

When Bootloader is selected, then Legacy Console Redirection is disabled before booting to legacy OS. When Always Enable is selected, then Legacy Console Redirection is enabled for legacy OS. Default setting for this option is set to Always Enable.
Select a COM port to display redirection of Legacy OS and Legacy OPROM Messages
Console Redirection Enable or Disable.
The settings specify how the host computer and the remote computer (which the user is using) will exchange data. Both computers should have the same or compatible settings.
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Console Redirection$3

Information.Help: Microsoft Windows Emergency Management Services (EMS) allows for remote management of a Windows Server OS through a serial port.

VT-UTF8 is the preferred terminal type for out-of-band management. The next best choice is VT100+ and then VT100. See above, in Console Redirection Settings page, for more Help with Terminal Type/Emulation.
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Console Redirection$3

Information.Help: Selects serial port transmission speed. The speed must be matched on the other side. Long or noisy lines may require lower speeds.
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Console Redirection$3

Information.Help: Flow control can prevent data loss from buffer overflow. When sending data, if the receiving buffers are full, a 'stop' signal can be sent to stop the data flow. Once the buffers are empty, a 'start' signal can be sent to re-start the flow. Hardware flow control uses two wires to send start/stop signals.
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Console Redirection$3

Menu.name: Change SMBIOS Event Log Settings

Information.Help: Press <Enter> to change the SMBIOS Event Log configuration.

Menu.Subtitle: Enabling/Disabling Options

Information.Help: Change this to enable or disable all features of SMBIOS Event Logging during boot.

Menu.Subtitle: Erasing Settings

Information.Help: Choose options for erasing SMBIOS Event Log. Erasing is done prior to any logging activation during reset.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != SMBIOS Event Log )

Information.Help: Choose options for reactions to a full SMBIOS Event Log.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != SMBIOS Event Log )

Menu.Subtitle: SMBIOS Event Log Standard Settings

Information.Help: Choose option to enable/disable logging of System boot event
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != SMBIOS Event Log )

Information.Help: Mutiple Event Count Increment: The number of occurrences of a duplicate event that must pass before the multiple-event counter of log entry is updated.The value ranges from 1 to 255.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != SMBIOS Event Log )

Information.Help: Multiple Event Time Window: The number of minutes which must pass between duplicate log entries which utilize a multiple-event counter. The value ranges from 0 to 99 minutes.
Information.WorkIf: ( 0 != SMBIOS Event Log )

Menu.Subtitle: NOTE: All values changed here do not take effect
until computer is restarted.

Information.Help: Press <Enter> to view the SMBIOS Event Log records.

Menu.name: Security
Menu.Subtitle: Password Description
If the Administrator's / User's password is set,
then this only limits access to Setup and is
asked for when entering Setup.
Please set Administrator's password first in order
to set User's password, if clear Administrator's
password, the User's password will be cleared as well.
The password length must be in the following range:
in the following range:

Information.Help: Set Administrator Password
Set User Password
Information.WorkIf: 0 != Administrator Password

Information.Help: Setup: Check password while invoking setup. Always: Check password while invoking setup as well as on each boot.
Enable/Disable BIOS Security Frozen Command to SATA and NVME Devices

Password: When SATA user password was set, device and password can be erased by SATA user password. Without Password: System will set a default password 111111111 for SATA user password, and erase device with 111111111 . If SATA user password is set, system will return fail status.
SMCI HDD Security function

Password: When SATA user password was set, device and password can be erased by SATA user password. Without Password: System will set a default password 111111111 for SATA user password, and erase device with 111111111 . If SATA user password is set, system will return fail status.
SMCI HDD Security function

Password: When SATA user password was set, device and password can be erased by SATA user password. Without Password: System will set a default password 111111111 for SATA user password, and erase device with 111111111 . If SATA user password is set, system will return fail status.
SMCI HDD Security function

Password: When SATA user password was set, device and password can be erased by SATA user password. Without Password: System will set a default password 111111111 for SATA user password, and erase device with 111111111 . If SATA user password is set, system will return fail status.
SMCI HDD Security function

Password: When TCG admin password was set, device and password can be erased by TCG admin password. If TCG admin password was not set, device is erased by MSID. PSID: Password and device are erased by PSID. Without Password: When TCG admin password was not set, don't need to input password/PSID. If TCG admin password was set, system return error status.
SMCI HDD Security function

Menu.Subtitle: HDD Security Configuration:

Menu.name: P1:Micron_5200_MTFDDAK7T6TDC

Information.Help: HDD Security Configuration for selected drive

Menu.Subtitle: HDD Password Description :
Allow Access to Set, Modify and Clear HardDisk User and Master
Password. User Password need to be installed for Enabling
Security. Master Password can be Modified only when
successfully unlocked with Master Password in POST. If the
'Set HDD Password' option is grayed out, do power cycle to
enable the option again.
HDD PASSWORD CONFIGURATION:

TCG Storage Security Configuration:

Menu.name: PCIe SSD

Information.Help: TCG Storage device Security Configuration

Menu.Subtitle: TCG Storage Security Password Description :
Allows access to Set, Modify and Clear TCG Storage device Admin and User Password.
Admin Password must be installed at first to enable TCG Storage Security. User Password can be created only when Admin password is installed.
TCG Storage device can be locked and unlocked using Admin password alone, User password acts as optional credential to unlock the Device in POST.
Set Admin/User Password options are greyed out when System enters Setup after Boot fail as Device security is frozen. Power-off, Power-on and press hot key to enter into setup.
PASSWORD CONFIGURATION:

Information.Help: Resets the device using 32 byte PSID (Physical Security Identification) value of the device. PSID revert resets the device to Original Factory State and it will completely erases the user data from drive. It is case sensitive
